sen.j: 志野流（しのりゅう）は香道および茶道流派の一つ。
sen.e: The Shino school is one of the schools of Kodo (traditional incense-smelling ceremony) and tea ceremony.

sen.j: 初代志野宗信は足利将軍家の6代足利義教から8代足利義政まで仕えた近臣であった。
sen.e: Soshin SHINO, the first-generation head of the clan, was a trusted vassal who devoted himself to the Ashikaga shogun family, through the sixth shogun, Yoshinori ASHIKAGA to the eighth, Yoshiie ASHIKAGA.

sen.j: 3代志野省巴は千利休を含む多くの門人を抱えたが、隠棲するにあたってその一切を建部隆勝に預け、建部隆勝の推により志野流は蜂谷宗悟に受け継がれたと伝えられる。
sen.e: Shoha SINO, the third-generation head of the clan, held a large following of pupils including SEN no Rikyu and retiring from his position, he left everything to Ryusho TATEBE; thus under the recommendation of Ryusho TATEBE, Sogo HACHIYA is said to have succeeded to the Shino school.

sen.j: 一方で米川流の祖米川常伯のように蜂谷家とは独立に建部隆勝の流れを汲むものもいて、これらを建部流と称することがある。
sen.e: On the other hand, some schools were independent of the Hachiya family, such as Johaku YONEKAWA, a founder of the Yonekawa school, following the style of Ryusho TATEBE, and those are sometimes known as the Takebe school.

sen.j: 9世宗先は元禄期の時流に沿って家元制度を確立させ、志野流の中興と称せられる。
sen.e: Sosen, the ninth tea master of the Shino school, established the iemoto system (the system of licensing the teaching of a traditional Japanese art), catching the tide of the Genroku period (the period when culture, especially among chonin (townspeople) flowered), so that he was called as the restorer of the Shino school.

sen.j: 藤野専斎昌章（1701年 - 1783年）は宗先の高弟で、宗先の没した後4代に渡って後見を務め、40年に及ぶ宗家継承の難局を乗り切った。
sen.e: Masaaki Sensai FUJIMO(1701-1783), a high-ranked disciple of Sosen, overcame the difficulty of the Shino family's succession for forty years, acting as a guardian for four-subsequent-generation heads of the school after the death of Sosen.

sen.e: During the time of the fifteenth master, Soi, the residence of the Shino family burned to the ground as a result of a fire caused by Kinmon Incident in 1864, moving to Nagoya under the wing of the Owari family.

sen.e: The incense-smelling ceremony declined after the Meiji Restoration as well as other public entertainments, but after the World War II, it made a comeback and now there are two branches; the Shino school and the Oie school.

sen.j: 一方で鳥取藩の支藩鳥取東館の池田仲雅が志野流の茶道を好み、流祖像を作り大谷平奉弘を茶頭として志野流茶道を指導させたことから、志野流の元来の茶道が因幡地方に伝来することになった。
sen.e: On the other hand, the original tea ceremony style of the Shino school was passed on in the Inaba region because Nakamasa IKEDA, a lord of the Tottoi Higashi Yakata, which was the branch domain of Tottiri, preferred the style of the Shino school of the tea ceremony, built the statue of its founder, and let 大谷平奉弘 teach that style as sado (a person in charge of the tea ceremony).
